member.name: T:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext
member.summary: ApplicationContext provides contextual information about an application thread. Specifically this allows an application author to redifine what circurmstances cause a message loop to exit. By default the application context listens to the close event on the mainForm, then exits the thread's message loop.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new ApplicationContext with no mainForm.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.#ctor(System.Windows.Forms.Form)
member.summary: Creates a new ApplicationContext with the specified mainForm. If OnMainFormClosed is not overriden, the thread's message loop will be terminated when mainForm is closed.

member.name: P:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.MainForm
member.summary: Determines the mainForm for this context. This may be changed at anytime. If OnMainFormClosed is not overriden, the thread's message loop will be terminated when mainForm is closed.

member.name: E:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.ThreadExit
member.summary: Is raised when the thread's message loop should be terminated. This is raised by calling ExitThread.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes the context. This should dispose the mainForm. This is called immediately after the thread's message loop is terminated. Application will dispose all forms on this thread by default.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.ExitThread
member.summary: Causes the thread's message loop to be terminated. This will call ExitThreadCore.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.ExitThreadCore
member.summary: Causes the thread's message loop to be terminated.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.OnMainFormClosed(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Called when the mainForm is closed. The default implementation of this will call ExitThreadCore.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext.OnMainFormDestroy(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Called when the mainForm is closed. The default implementation of this will call ExitThreadCore.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Forms.FormCollection

The default implementation will make a call to ToString on the object if the object is valid and if the destination type is string. If this cannot convert to the desitnation type, this will throw a NotSupportedException.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.KeysConverter.GetStandardValues(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext)
member.summary: Retrieves a collection containing a set of standard values for the data type this validator is designed for. This will return null if the data type does not support a standard set of values.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.KeysConverter.GetStandardValuesExclusive(System.ComponentModel.ITypeDescriptorContext)
member.summary: Determines if the list of standard values returned from GetStandardValues is an exclusive list. If the list is exclusive, then no other values are valid, such as in an enum data type. If the list is not exclusive, then there are other valid values besides the list of standard values GetStandardValues provides.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Forms.BindingContext
member.summary: Manages the collection of System.Windows.Forms.BindingManagerBase objects for a Win Form.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.BindingManagerBase.OnBindingsCollectionChanged(System.Object,System.ComponentModel.CollectionChangeEventArgs)
member.summary:
BindingComplete events on individual Bindings are propagated up through the BindingComplete event on the owning BindingManagerBase. To do this, we have to track changes to the bindings collection, adding or removing handlers on items in the collection as appropriate.
For the Add and Remove cases, we hook the collection 'changed' event, and add or remove handler for specific binding.
For the Refresh case, we hook both the 'changing' and 'changed' events, removing handlers for all items that were in the collection before the change, then adding handlers for whatever items are in the collection after the change.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Forms.ItemArray
member.summary:
This is similar to ArrayList except that it also maintains a bit-flag based state element for each item in the array.
The methods to enumerate, count and get data support virtualized indexes. Indexes are virtualized according to the state mask passed in. This allows ItemArray to be the backing store for one read-write "master" collection and several read-only collections based on masks. ItemArray supports up to 31 masks.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyStore.CreateKey
member.summary: Creates a new key for this property store. This is NOT guarded by any thread safety so if you are calling it on multiple threads you should guard. For our purposes, we're fine because this is designed to be called in a class initializer, and we never have the same class hierarchy initializing on multiple threads at once.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyStore.LocateIntegerEntry(System.Int16,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Locates the requested entry in our array if entries. This does not do the mask check to see if the entry is currently being used, but it does locate the entry. If the entry is found, this returns true and fills in index and element. If the entry is not found, this returns false. If the entry is not found, index will contain the insert point at which one would add a new element.

member.summary: Locates the requested entry in our array if entries. This does not do the mask check to see if the entry is currently being used, but it does locate the entry. If the entry is found, this returns true and fills in index and element. If the entry is not found, this returns false. If the entry is not found, index will contain the insert point at which one would add a new element.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.ContainerControl
member.summary: Indicates whether the control is a container-like control.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.UserPaint
member.summary: The control paints itself; WM_PAINT and WM_ERASEBKGND messages are not passed on to the underlying NativeWindow. This style only applies to subclasses of Control.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.Opaque
member.summary: If specified, a PaintBackground event will not be raised, OnPaintBackground will not be called, and Invalidate() will not invalidate the background of the HWND.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.ResizeRedraw
member.summary: The control is completely redrawn when it is resized.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.FixedWidth
member.summary: The control has a fixed width.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.FixedHeight
member.summary: The control has a fixed height.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.StandardClick
member.summary: If set, windows forms calls OnClick and raises the Click event when the control is clicked (unless it's the second click of a double-click and StandardDoubleClick is specified). Regardless of this style, the control may call OnClick directly.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.Selectable
member.summary: The control can get the focus.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.UserMouse
member.summary: The control does its own mouse processing; WM_MOUSEDOWN, WM_MOUSEMOVE, and WM_MOUSEUP messages are not passed on to the underlying NativeWindow.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.SupportsTransparentBackColor
member.summary: If the BackColor is set to a color whose alpha component is less than 255 (i.e., BackColor.A is less than 255), OnPaintBackground will simulate transparency by asking its parent control to paint our background. This is not true transparency -- if there is another control between us and our parent, we will not show the control in the middle. This style only applies to subclasses of Control. It only works if UserPaint is set, and the parent control is a Control.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.StandardDoubleClick
member.summary: If set, windows forms calls OnDoubleClick and raises the DoubleClick event when the control is double clicked. Regardless of whether it is set, the control may call OnDoubleClick directly. This style is ignored if StandardClick is not set.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.AllPaintingInWmPaint
member.summary: If true, WM_ERASEBKGND is ignored, and both OnPaintBackground and OnPaint are called directly from WM_PAINT. This generally reduces flicker, but can cause problems if other controls send WM_ERASEBKGND messages to us. (This is sometimes done to achieve a pseudo-transparent effect similar to ControlStyles.SupportsTransparentBackColor; for instance, ToolBar with flat appearance does this). This style only makes sense if UserPaint is true.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.CacheText
member.summary: If true, the control keeps a copy of the text rather than going to the hWnd for the text every time. This improves performance but makes it difficult to keep the control and hWnd's text synchronized. This style defaults to false.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.EnableNotifyMessage
member.summary: If true, the OnNotifyMessage method will be called for every message sent to the control's WndProc. This style defaults to false.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.DoubleBuffer
member.summary: If set, all control painting will be double buffered. You must also set the UserPaint and AllPaintingInWmPaint style. Note: This is obsolete, please use OptimizedDoubleBuffer instead.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.OptimizedDoubleBuffer
member.summary: If set, all control painting will be double buffered.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles.UseTextForAccessibility
member.summary:
If this style is set, and there is a value in the control's Text property, that value will be used to determine the control's default Active Accessibility name and shortcut key. Otherwise, the text of the preceding Label control will be used instead.
This style is set by default. Certain built-in control types such as TextBox and ComboBox un-set this style, so that their current text will not be used by Active Accessibility.

member.name: P:System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams.ClassName
member.summary: Name of the window class to subclass. The default value for this field is null, indicating that the window is not a subclass of an existing window class. To subclass an existing window class, store the window class name in this field. For example, to subclass the standard edit control, set this field to "EDIT".

member.name: T:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents
member.summary: Specifies events that are reported by accessible applications.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.SystemSound
member.summary: EVENT_SYSTEM_SOUND Sent when a sound is played. Currently nothing is generating this, we are going to be cleaning up the SOUNDSENTRY feature in the control panel and will use this at that time. Applications implementing WinEvents are perfectly welcome to use it. Clients of IAccessible* will simply turn around and get back a non-visual object that describes the sound.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.SystemAlert
member.summary: EVENT_SYSTEM_ALERT Sent when an alert needs to be given to the user. MessageBoxes generate alerts for example.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.SystemForeground
member.summary: EVENT_SYSTEM_FOREGROUND Sent when the foreground (active) window changes, even if it is changing to another window in the same thread as the previous one.

members.member:
EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUSTART Sent when entering into menu mode (system, app bar, and track popups).
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUEND Sent when leaving from menu mode (system, app bar, and track popups).
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUPOPUPSTART Sent when a menu popup comes up.
Note that for a call to TrackPopupMenu(), a client will see EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUSTART followed almost immediately by EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUPOPUPSTART for the popup being shown.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUPOPUPEND Sent when a menu popup just before it is taken down.
Note that for a call to TrackPopupMenu(), a client will see EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUSTART followed almost immediately by EVENT_SYSTEM_MENUPOPUPSTART for the popup being shown.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_CAPTURESTART Sent when a window takes the capture.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_CAPTUREEND Sent when a window releases the capture.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_MOVESIZESTART Sent when a window enters move-size dragging mode.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_MOVESIZEEND Sent when a window leaves move-size dragging mode.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_CONTEXTHELPSTART Sent when a window enters context sensitive help mode.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_CONTEXTHELPEND Sent when a window leaves context sensitive help mode.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_DRAGDROPSTART Sent when a window enters drag drop mode.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_DRAGDROPEND Sent when a window leaves drag drop mode.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_DIALOGSTART Sent when a dialog comes up.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_DIALOGEND Sent when a dialog just before it goes away.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_SCROLLINGSTART Sent when beginning the tracking of a scrollbar in a window, and also for scrollbar controls.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_SCROLLINGEND Sent when ending the tracking of a scrollbar in a window, and also for scrollbar controls.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_SWITCHSTART Sent when beginning alt-tab mode with the switch window.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_SWITCHEND Sent when ending alt-tab mode with the switch window.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_MINIMIZESTART Sent when a window minimizes and just before it restores.
.

EVENT_SYSTEM_MINIMIZEEND Sent when a window minimizes and just before it restores.
.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.Create
member.summary: EVENT_OBJECT_CREATE Sent when an object has been created. The system sends this event for the following user interface elements: caret, header control, list-view control, tab control, toolbar control, tree view control, and window object. Server applications send this event for their accessible objects.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.Destroy
member.summary: EVENT_OBJECT_DESTROY Sent when an object has been destroyed. The system sends this event for the following user interface elements: caret, header control, list-view control, tab control, toolbar control, tree view control, and window object. Server applications send this event for their accessible objects.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.Show
member.summary: EVENT_OBJECT_SHOW Sent when a hidden object is shown. The system sends this event for the following user interface elements: caret, cursor, and window object. Server applications send this event for their accessible objects. Clients assume that when this event is sent by a parent object, all child objects are already displayed. Therefore, server applications do not send this event for the child objects.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.Hide
member.summary: EVENT_OBJECT_HIDE Sent when an object is hidden. The system sends this event for the following user interface elements: caret and cursor. Server applications send this event for their accessible objects. When this event is generated for a parent object, all child objects are already hidden. Server applications do not send this event for the child objects.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.Reorder
member.summary: EVENT_OBJECT_REORDER Sent when a container object has added, removed, or reordered its children. The system sends this event for the following user interface elements: header control, list-view control, toolbar control, and window object. Server applications send this event as appropriate for their accessible objects.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.Focus
member.summary: Minimize the number of notifications! When you are hiding a parent object, obviously all child objects are no longer visible on screen. They still have the same "visible" status, but are not truly visible. Hence do not send HIDE notifications for the children also. One implies all. The same goes for SHOW.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleEvents.StateChange
member.summary:
There is only one "focused" child item in a parent. This is the place keystrokes are going at a given moment. Hence only send a notification about where the NEW focus is going. A NEW item getting the focus already implies that the OLD item is losing it.
SELECTION however can be multiple. Hence the different SELECTION notifications. Here's when to use each:
(1) Send a SELECTION notification in the simple single selection case (like the focus) when the item with the selection is merely moving to a different item within a container. hwnd + ID is the container control, idChildItem is the new child with the selection.
(2) Send a SELECTIONADD notification when a new item has simply been added to the selection within a container. This is appropriate when the number of newly selected items is very small. hwnd + ID is the container control, idChildItem is the new child added to the selection.
(3) Send a SELECTIONREMOVE notification when a new item has simply been removed from the selection within a container. This is appropriate when the number of newly selected items is very small, just like SELECTIONADD. hwnd + ID is the container control, idChildItem is the new child removed from the selection.
(4) Send a SELECTIONWITHIN notification when the selected items within a control have changed substantially. Rather than propagate a large number of changes to reflect removal for some items, addition of others, just tell somebody who cares that a lot happened. It will be faster an easier for somebody watching to just turn around and query the container control what the new bunch of selected items are.

member.summary: The default button or menu item.

member.summary: A control that cannot accept input in its current condition.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Floating
member.summary: The object is not fixed to the boundary of its parent object, and does not move automatically along with the parent.

member.summary: An object with scrolling or moving text or graphics.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Animated
member.summary: The object has a rapidly or constantly changing appearance. Graphics that are occasionally animated, but not always, should be defined as |. This state should not be used to indicate that the object's location is changing.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Invisible
member.summary: An object that is currently invisible.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Offscreen
member.summary: No on-screen representation. A sound or alert object would have this state, or a hidden window that is never made visible.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Sizeable
member.summary: A sizable object.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Moveable
member.summary: A movable object.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.SelfVoicing
member.summary: The object or child can use text-to-speech (TTS) to describe itself. A speech-based accessibility aid should not announce information when an object with this state has the focus because the object will automatically announce information about itself.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Focusable
member.summary: The object is on the active window and can receive keyboard focus.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Selectable
member.summary: An object that can accept selection.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Linked
member.summary: A linked object that has not been previously selected.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Traversed
member.summary: A linked object that has previously been selected.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.MultiSelectable
member.summary: An object that accepts multiple selected items.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.ExtSelectable
member.summary: Alters the selection so that all objects between the selection anchor, which is the object with the keyboard focus, and this object take on the anchor object's selection state. If the anchor object is not selected, the objects are removed from the selection. If the anchor object is selected, the selection is extended to include this object and all the objects in between. You can set the selection state by combining this flag with or . This flag does not change the focus or the selection anchor unless it is combined with . The behavior of | is equivalent to adding an item to a selection manually by holding down the SHIFT key and clicking an unselected object. This flag may not be combined with .

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.AlertLow
member.summary: Low-priority information that may not be important to the user.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.AlertMedium
member.summary: Important information that does not need to be conveyed to the user immediately. For example, when a battery level indicator is starting to reach a low level, it could generate a medium-level alert. Blind access utilities could then generate a sound to let the user know that important information is available, without actually interrupting the user's work. The user could then query the alert information at their leisure.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.AlertHigh
member.summary: Important information that should be conveyed to the user immediately. For example, a battery level indicator reaching a critical low level would transition to this state, in which case a blind access utility would announce this information immediately to the user, and a screen magnification program would scroll the screen so that the battery indicator is in view. This state is also appropriate for any prompt or operation that must be completed before the user can continue.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Protected
member.summary: A password-protected edit control.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.HasPopup
member.summary: Object displays a pop-up menu or window when invoked.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AutoSizeMode.GrowAndShrink
member.summary: The same behavior as you get for controls with AutoSize and no AutoSizeMode property. The control will grow or shrink to encompass the contents (e.g. text for a Button, child controls for a container). The MinimumSize and MaximumSize are followed, but the current value of the Size property is ignored.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.AutoSizeMode.GrowOnly
member.summary: The control will grow as much as it needs to encompass its contents (e.g. text for a button, child controls for a container), but will not shrink smaller than its Size, whichever is larger.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Forms.ValidationConstraints
member.summary: Determines which child controls in a ContainerControl will be validated by the method.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ValidationConstraints.None
member.summary: All child controls and their descendants are validated.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ValidationConstraints.Selectable
member.summary:
Child control must be selectable to be validated.
Note: This flag allows validation of a control that has the ControlStyles.Selectable style, ie. has the ability to be selected, even when that control is currently unselectable because it has been disabled or hidden. To prevent validation of selectable controls that are currently disabled or hidden,

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ValidationConstraints.Enabled
member.summary: Child control must be enabled to be validated (Control.Enabled = true).

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ValidationConstraints.Visible
member.summary: Child control must be visible to be validated (Control.Visible = true).

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ValidationConstraints.TabStop
member.summary: Child control must be a tab stops to be validated (Control.TabStop = true).

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.ValidationConstraints.ImmediateChildren
member.summary: Only immediate children of container control are validated. Descendants are not validated.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs.ResetGraphics
member.summary: If ControlStyles.AllPaintingInWmPaint, we call this method after OnPaintBackground so it appears to OnPaint that it's getting a fresh Graphics. We want to make sure AllPaintingInWmPaint is purely an optimization, and doesn't change behavior, so we need to make sure any clipping regions established in OnPaintBackground don't apply to OnPaint.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Forms.ClientUtils.GetWordBoundaryStart(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Imitates the backwards word selection logic of the native SHAutoComplete Ctrl+Backspace handler. The selection will consist of any run of word characters and any run of non-word characters at the end of that word. If the selection reaches the second character in the input, and the first character is non-word, it is also selected. Here, word characters are equivalent to the "\w" regex class but with UnicodeCategory.ConnectorPunctuation excluded.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.BitOperations
member.summary: Utility methods for intrinsic bit-twiddling operations. The methods use hardware intrinsics when available on the underlying platform, otherwise they use optimized software fallbacks.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.BitOperations.RotateLeft(System.UInt32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Rotates the specified value left by the specified number of bits. Similar in behavior to the x86 instruction ROL.
member.param: The value to rotate.
The number of bits to rotate by. Any value outside the range [0..31] is treated as congruent mod 32.
member.returns: The rotated value.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.BitOperations.RotateLeft(System.UInt64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Rotates the specified value left by the specified number of bits. Similar in behavior to the x86 instruction ROL.
member.param: The value to rotate.
The number of bits to rotate by. Any value outside the range [0..63] is treated as congruent mod 64.
member.returns: The rotated value.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.BitOperations.RotateLeft(System.UIntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: Rotates the specified value left by the specified number of bits. Similar in behavior to the x86 instruction ROL.
member.param: The value to rotate.

The number of bits to rotate by. Any value outside the range [0..31] is treated as congruent mod 32 on a 32-bit process, and any value outside the range [0..63] is treated as congruent mod 64 on a 64-bit process.
member.returns: The rotated value.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.BitOperations.RotateRight(System.UInt32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Rotates the specified value right by the specified number of bits. Similar in behavior to the x86 instruction ROR.
member.param: The value to rotate.
The number of bits to rotate by. Any value outside the range [0..31] is treated as congruent mod 32.
member.returns: The rotated value.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.BitOperations.RotateRight(System.UInt64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Rotates the specified value right by the specified number of bits. Similar in behavior to the x86 instruction ROR.
member.param: The value to rotate.
The number of bits to rotate by. Any value outside the range [0..63] is treated as congruent mod 64.
member.returns: The rotated value.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.BitOperations.RotateRight(System.UIntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: Rotates the specified value right by the specified number of bits. Similar in behavior to the x86 instruction ROR.
member.param: The value to rotate.

The number of bits to rotate by. Any value outside the range [0..31] is treated as congruent mod 32 on a 32-bit process, and any value outside the range [0..63] is treated as congruent mod 64 on a 64-bit process.
member.returns: The rotated value.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation
member.summary: Determines how the source color in a copy pixel operation is combined with the destination color to result in a final color.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.NoMirrorBitmap
member.summary: The bitmap is not mirrored.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.Blackness
member.summary: The destination area is filled by using the color associated with index 0 in the physical palette. (This color is black for the default physical palette.)

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.NotSourceErase
member.summary: The source and destination colors are combined using the Boolean operator, and then resultant color is then inverted.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.NotSourceCopy
member.summary: The inverted source area is copied to the destination.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.SourceErase
member.summary: The inverted colors of the destination area are combined with the colors of the source area using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.DestinationInvert
member.summary: The destination area is inverted.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.PatInvert
member.summary: The colors of the brush currently selected in the destination device context are combined with the colors of the destination are using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.SourceInvert
member.summary: The colors of the source and destination areas are combined using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.SourceAnd
member.summary: The colors of the source and destination areas are combined using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.MergePaint
member.summary: The colors of the inverted source area are merged with the colors of the destination area by using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.MergeCopy
member.summary: The colors of the source area are merged with the colors of the selected brush of the destination device context using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.SourceCopy
member.summary: The source area is copied directly to the destination area.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.SourcePaint
member.summary: The colors of the source and destination areas are combined using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.PatCopy
member.summary: The brush currently selected in the destination device context is copied to the destination bitmap.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.PatPaint
member.summary: The colors of the brush currently selected in the destination device context are combined with the colors of the inverted source area using the Boolean operator. The result of this operation is combined with the colors of the destination area using the Boolean operator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.Whiteness
member.summary: The destination area is filled by using the color associated with index 1 in the physical palette. (This color is white for the default physical palette.)

member.name: F:System.Drawing.CopyPixelOperation.CaptureBlt
member.summary: Windows that are layered on top of your window are included in the resulting image. By default, the image contains only your window. Note that this generally cannot be used for printing device contexts.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath.StartFigure
member.summary: Starts a new figure without closing the current figure. All subsequent points added to the path are added to this new figure.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath.CloseAllFigures
member.summary: Closes all open figures in this path and starts a new figure. It closes each open figure by connecting a line from its endpoint to its starting point.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath.CloseFigure
member.summary: Closes the current figure and starts a new figure. If the current figure contains a sequence of connected lines and curves, the method closes the loop by connecting a line from the endpoint to the starting point.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath.Flatten(System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix,System.Single)
member.summary: Converts each curve in this into a sequence of connected line segments.
member.param: A by which to transform this before flattening.

Specifies the maximum permitted error between the curve and its flattened approximation. A value of 0.25 is the default. Reducing the flatness value will increase the number of line segments in the approximation.

member.summary: Creates a gradient with a center color and a linear falloff to one surrounding color.

A value from 0 through 1 that specifies the maximum intensity of the center color that gets blended with the boundary color. A value of 1 causes the highest possible intensity of the center color, and it is the default value.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.Imaging.EmfType
member.summary: Specifies the nature of the records that are placed in an Enhanced Metafile (EMF) file. This enumeration is used by several constructors in the class.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EmfType.EmfOnly
member.summary: Specifies that all the records in the metafile are EMF records, which can be displayed by GDI or GDI+.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EmfType.EmfPlusOnly
member.summary: Specifies that all the records in the metafile are EMF+ records, which can be displayed by GDI+ but not by GDI.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EmfType.EmfPlusDual
member.summary: Specifies that all EMF+ records in the metafile are associated with an alternate EMF record. Metafiles of type can be displayed by GDI or by GDI+.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameter.#ctor(System.Drawing.Imaging.Encoder,System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified object and two arrays of 32-bit integers. The two arrays represent an array of fractions. Sets the property to , and sets the property to the number of elements in the array, which must be the same as the number of elements in the array.
member.param: An object that encapsulates the globally unique identifier of the parameter category.
An array of 32-bit integers that specifies the numerators of the fractions. The integers in the array must be nonnegative.

An array of 32-bit integers that specifies the denominators of the fractions. The integers in the array must be nonnegative. A denominator of a given index is paired with the numerator of the same index.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameter.#ctor(System.Drawing.Imaging.Encoder,System.Int64[],System.Int64[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified object and two arrays of 64-bit integers. The two arrays represent an array integer ranges. Sets the property to , and sets the property to the number of elements in the array, which must be the same as the number of elements in the array.
member.param: An object that encapsulates the globally unique identifier of the parameter category.

An array of 64-bit integers that specifies the minimum values for the integer ranges. The integers in the array must be nonnegative. The 64-bit integers are converted to 32-bit integers before they are stored in the object.

An array of 64-bit integers that specifies the maximum values for the integer ranges. The integers in the array must be nonnegative. The 64-bit integers are converted to 32-bit integers before they are stored in the object. A maximum value of a given index is paired with the minimum value of the same index.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameter.#ctor(System.Drawing.Imaging.Encoder,System.Int32[],System.Int32[],System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified object and four arrays of 32-bit integers. The four arrays represent an array rational ranges. A rational range is the set of all fractions from a minimum fractional value through a maximum fractional value. Sets the property to , and sets the property to the number of elements in the array, which must be the same as the number of elements in the other three arrays.
member.param: An object that encapsulates the globally unique identifier of the parameter category.
An array of 32-bit integers that specifies the numerators of the minimum values for the ranges. The integers in the array must be nonnegative.
An array of 32-bit integers that specifies the denominators of the minimum values for the ranges. The integers in the array must be nonnegative.
An array of 32-bit integers that specifies the numerators of the maximum values for the ranges. The integers in the array must be nonnegative.
An array of 32-bit integers that specifies the denominators of the maximum values for the ranges. The integers in the array must be nonnegative.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType
member.summary: Used to specify the data type of the used with the or method of an image.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeByte
member.summary: Specifies that each value in the array is an 8-bit unsigned integer.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeAscii
member.summary: Specifies that the array of values is a null-terminated ASCII character string. Note that the data member of the object indicates the length of the character string including the NULL terminator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeShort
member.summary: Specifies that each value in the array is a 16-bit, unsigned integer.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeLong
member.summary: Specifies that each value in the array is a 32-bit unsigned integer.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeRational
member.summary: Specifies that each value in the array is a pair of 32-bit unsigned integers. Each pair represents a fraction, the first integer being the numerator and the second integer being the denominator.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeLongRange
member.summary: Specifies that each value in the array is a pair of 32-bit unsigned integers. Each pair represents a range of numbers.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeUndefined
member.summary: Specifies that the array of values is an array of bytes that has no data type defined.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderParameterValueType.ValueTypeRationalRange
member.summary: Specifies that each value in the array is a set of four, 32-bit unsigned integers. The first two integers represent one fraction, and the second two integers represent a second fraction. The two fractions represent a range of rational numbers. The first fraction is the smallest rational number in the range, and the second fraction is the largest rational number in the range.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderValue
member.summary: Used to specify the parameter value passed to a JPEG or TIFF image encoder when using the or methods.

member.summary: Not used in GDI+ version 1.0.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderValue.ColorTypeYCCK
member.summary: Not used in GDI+ version 1.0.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderValue.CompressionLZW
member.summary: Specifies the LZW compression scheme. Can be passed to the TIFF encoder as a parameter that belongs to the Compression category.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderValue.CompressionCCITT3

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderValue.CompressionCCITT4
member.summary: Specifies the CCITT4 compression scheme. Can be passed to the TIFF encoder as a parameter that belongs to the compression category.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderValue.CompressionRle
member.summary: Specifies the RLE compression scheme. Can be passed to the TIFF encoder as a parameter that belongs to the compression category.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.EncoderValue.CompressionNone
member.summary: Specifies no compression. Can be passed to the TIFF encoder as a parameter that belongs to the compression category.

member.summary: Not used in GDI+ version 1.0.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.Imaging.MetafileType
member.summary: Specifies types of metafiles. The property returns a member of this enumeration.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.MetafileType.Invalid
member.summary: Specifies a metafile format that is not recognized in GDI+.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.MetafileType.Wmf
member.summary: Specifies a WMF (Windows Metafile) file. Such a file contains only GDI records.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.MetafileType.WmfPlaceable
member.summary: Specifies a WMF (Windows Metafile) file that has a placeable metafile header in front of it.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.MetafileType.Emf
member.summary: Specifies an Enhanced Metafile (EMF) file. Such a file contains only GDI records.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.MetafileType.EmfPlusOnly
member.summary: Specifies an EMF+ file. Such a file contains only GDI+ records and must be displayed by using GDI+. Displaying the records using GDI may cause unpredictable results.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.MetafileType.EmfPlusDual
member.summary: Specifies an EMF+ Dual file. Such a file contains GDI+ records along with alternative GDI records and can be displayed by using either GDI or GDI+. Displaying the records using GDI may cause some quality degradation.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Indexed
member.summary: The pixel data contains color-indexed values, which means the values are an index to colors in the system color table, as opposed to individual color values.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Gdi
member.summary: The pixel data contains GDI colors.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Alpha
member.summary: The pixel data contains alpha values that are not premultiplied.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.PAlpha
member.summary: The pixel format contains premultiplied alpha values.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Extended
member.summary: Reserved.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Canonical
member.summary: The default pixel format of 32 bits per pixel. The format specifies 24-bit color depth and an 8-bit alpha channel.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Undefined
member.summary: The pixel format is undefined.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.DontCare
member.summary: No pixel format is specified.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format1bppIndexed
member.summary: Specifies that the pixel format is 1 bit per pixel and that it uses indexed color. The color table therefore has two colors in it.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format4bppIndexed
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 4 bits per pixel, indexed.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format8bppIndexed
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 8 bits per pixel, indexed. The color table therefore has 256 colors in it.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format16bppGrayScale
member.summary: The pixel format is 16 bits per pixel. The color information specifies 65536 shades of gray.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format16bppRgb555
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 16 bits per pixel; 5 bits each are used for the red, green, and blue components. The remaining bit is not used.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format16bppRgb565
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 16 bits per pixel; 5 bits are used for the red component, 6 bits are used for the green component, and 5 bits are used for the blue component.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format16bppArgb1555
member.summary: The pixel format is 16 bits per pixel. The color information specifies 32,768 shades of color, of which 5 bits are red, 5 bits are green, 5 bits are blue, and 1 bit is alpha.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format24bppRgb
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 24 bits per pixel; 8 bits each are used for the red, green, and blue components.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format32bppRgb
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 32 bits per pixel; 8 bits each are used for the red, green, and blue components. The remaining 8 bits are not used.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format32bppArgb
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 32 bits per pixel; 8 bits each are used for the alpha, red, green, and blue components.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format32bppPArgb
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 32 bits per pixel; 8 bits each are used for the alpha, red, green, and blue components. The red, green, and blue components are premultiplied, according to the alpha component.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format48bppRgb
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 48 bits per pixel; 16 bits each are used for the red, green, and blue components.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format64bppArgb
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 64 bits per pixel; 16 bits each are used for the alpha, red, green, and blue components.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Format64bppPArgb
member.summary: Specifies that the format is 64 bits per pixel; 16 bits each are used for the alpha, red, green, and blue components. The red, green, and blue components are premultiplied according to the alpha component.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Imaging.PixelFormat.Max
member.summary: The maximum value for this enumeration.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.Text.TextRenderingHint
member.summary: Specifies the quality of text rendering.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Text.TextRenderingHint.SystemDefault
member.summary: Each character is drawn using its glyph bitmap, with the system default rendering hint. The text will be drawn using whatever font-smoothing settings the user has selected for the system.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Text.TextRenderingHint.SingleBitPerPixelGridFit
member.summary: Each character is drawn using its glyph bitmap. Hinting is used to improve character appearance on stems and curvature.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Text.TextRenderingHint.SingleBitPerPixel
member.summary: Each character is drawn using its glyph bitmap. Hinting is not used.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Text.TextRenderingHint.AntiAliasGridFit
member.summary: Each character is drawn using its antialiased glyph bitmap with hinting. Much better quality due to antialiasing, but at a higher performance cost.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Text.TextRenderingHint.AntiAlias
member.summary: Each character is drawn using its antialiased glyph bitmap without hinting. Better quality due to antialiasing. Stem width differences may be noticeable because hinting is turned off.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.Text.TextRenderingHint.ClearTypeGridFit
member.summary: Each character is drawn using its glyph ClearType bitmap with hinting. The highest quality setting. Used to take advantage of ClearType font features.

member.name: P:System.Drawing.Printing.QueryPageSettingsEventArgs.PageSettingsChanged
member.summary: It's too expensive to compare 2 instances of PageSettings class, as the getters are accessing the printer spooler, thus we track any explicit invocations of the setters or getters on this class, and this field tracks if PageSettings property was accessed. It will return a false positive when the user is reading property values, but we'll take a perf hit in this case assuming this event is not used often.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.StringAlignment
member.summary: Specifies the alignment of a text string relative to its layout rectangle.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringAlignment.Near
member.summary: Specifies the text be aligned near the layout. In a left-to-right layout, the near position is left. In a right-to-left layout, the near position is right.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringAlignment.Center
member.summary: Specifies that text is aligned in the center of the layout rectangle.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringAlignment.Far
member.summary: Specifies that text is aligned far from the origin position of the layout rectangle. In a left-to-right layout, the far position is right. In a right-to-left layout, the far position is left.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.StringDigitSubstitute
member.summary: The enumeration specifies how to substitute digits in a string according to a user's locale or language.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringDigitSubstitute.User
member.summary: Specifies a user-defined substitution scheme.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringDigitSubstitute.None
member.summary: Specifies to disable substitutions.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringDigitSubstitute.National
member.summary: Specifies substitution digits that correspond with the official national language of the user's locale.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringDigitSubstitute.Traditional
member.summary: Specifies substitution digits that correspond with the user's native script or language, which may be different from the official national language of the user's locale.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.StringFormat
member.summary: Encapsulates text layout information (such as alignment, orientation and tab stops) display manipulations (such as ellipsis insertion and national digit substitution) and OpenType features. This class cannot be inherited.

member.name: P:System.Drawing.StringFormat.Alignment
member.summary: Gets or sets horizontal alignment of the string.
member.returns: A enumeration that specifies the horizontal alignment of the string.

member.name: P:System.Drawing.StringFormat.DigitSubstitutionLanguage
member.summary: Gets the language that is used when local digits are substituted for western digits.
member.returns: A National Language Support (NLS) language identifier that identifies the language that will be used when local digits are substituted for western digits. You can pass the property of a object as the NLS language identifier. For example, suppose you create a object by passing the string "ar-EG" to a constructor. If you pass the property of that object along with to the method, then Arabic-Indic digits will be substituted for western digits at display time.

member.name: P:System.Drawing.StringFormat.DigitSubstitutionMethod
member.summary: Gets the method to be used for digit substitution.
member.returns: A enumeration value that specifies how to substitute characters in a string that cannot be displayed because they are not supported by the current font.

member.summary: Converts this object to a human-readable string.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags
member.summary: Specifies the display and layout information for text strings.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.DirectionRightToLeft
member.summary: Text is displayed from right to left.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.DirectionVertical
member.summary: Text is vertically aligned.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.FitBlackBox
member.summary: Parts of characters are allowed to overhang the string's layout rectangle. By default, characters are repositioned to avoid any overhang.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.DisplayFormatControl
member.summary: Control characters such as the left-to-right mark are shown in the output with a representative glyph.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.NoFontFallback
member.summary: Fallback to alternate fonts for characters not supported in the requested font is disabled. Any missing characters are displayed with the fonts missing glyph, usually an open square.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.MeasureTrailingSpaces
member.summary: Includes the trailing space at the end of each line. By default the boundary rectangle returned by the method excludes the space at the end of each line. Set this flag to include that space in measurement.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.NoWrap
member.summary: Text wrapping between lines when formatting within a rectangle is disabled. This flag is implied when a point is passed instead of a rectangle, or when the specified rectangle has a zero line length.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.LineLimit
member.summary: Only entire lines are laid out in the formatting rectangle. By default layout continues until the end of the text, or until no more lines are visible as a result of clipping, whichever comes first. Note that the default settings allow the last line to be partially obscured by a formatting rectangle that is not a whole multiple of the line height. To ensure that only whole lines are seen, specify this value and be careful to provide a formatting rectangle at least as tall as the height of one line.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.NoClip
member.summary: Overhanging parts of glyphs, and unwrapped text reaching outside the formatting rectangle are allowed to show. By default all text and glyph parts reaching outside the formatting rectangle are clipped.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.StringTrimming
member.summary: Specifies how to trim characters from a string that does not completely fit into a layout shape.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.None
member.summary: Specifies no trimming.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.Character
member.summary: Specifies that the text is trimmed to the nearest character.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.Word
member.summary: Specifies that text is trimmed to the nearest word.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.EllipsisCharacter
member.summary: Specifies that the text is trimmed to the nearest character, and an ellipsis is inserted at the end of a trimmed line.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.EllipsisWord
member.summary: Specifies that text is trimmed to the nearest word, and an ellipsis is inserted at the end of a trimmed line.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.EllipsisPath
member.summary: The center is removed from trimmed lines and replaced by an ellipsis. The algorithm keeps as much of the last slash-delimited segment of the line as possible.

member.summary: ResX File Reference class. This allows the developer to represent a link to an external resource. When the resource manager asks for the value of the resource item, the external resource is loaded.

member.summary: path1+result = path2 A string which is the relative path difference between path1 and path2 such that if path1 and the calculated difference are used as arguments to Combine(), path2 is returned

member.name: T:System.Resources.ResXNullRef
member.summary: ResX Null Reference class. This class allows ResX to store null values. It is a placeholder that is written into the file. On read, it is replaced with null.

member.name: P:System.Resources.ResXResourceReader.UseResXDataNodes
member.summary: ResXFileRef's TypeConverter automatically unwraps it, creates the referenced object and returns it. This property gives the user control over whether this unwrapping should happen, or a ResXFileRef object should be returned. Default is true for backward compat and common case scenario.

member.name: M:System.Drawing.StringFormat.SetDigitSubstitution(System.Int32,System.Drawing.StringDigitSubstitute)
member.summary: Specifies the language and method to be used when local digits are substituted for western digits.
member.param: A National Language Support (NLS) language identifier that identifies the language that will be used when local digits are substituted for western digits. You can pass the property of a object as the NLS language identifier. For example, suppose you create a object by passing the string "ar-EG" to a constructor. If you pass the property of that object along with to the method, then Arabic-Indic digits will be substituted for western digits at display time.
An element of the enumeration that specifies how digits are displayed.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags
member.summary: Specifies the display and layout information for text strings.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.DirectionRightToLeft
member.summary: Text is displayed from right to left.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.DirectionVertical
member.summary: Text is vertically aligned.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.FitBlackBox
member.summary: Parts of characters are allowed to overhang the string's layout rectangle. By default, characters are repositioned to avoid any overhang.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.DisplayFormatControl
member.summary: Control characters such as the left-to-right mark are shown in the output with a representative glyph.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.NoFontFallback
member.summary: Fallback to alternate fonts for characters not supported in the requested font is disabled. Any missing characters are displayed with the fonts missing glyph, usually an open square.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.MeasureTrailingSpaces
member.summary: Includes the trailing space at the end of each line. By default the boundary rectangle returned by the method excludes the space at the end of each line. Set this flag to include that space in measurement.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.NoWrap
member.summary: Text wrapping between lines when formatting within a rectangle is disabled. This flag is implied when a point is passed instead of a rectangle, or when the specified rectangle has a zero line length.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.LineLimit
member.summary: Only entire lines are laid out in the formatting rectangle. By default layout continues until the end of the text, or until no more lines are visible as a result of clipping, whichever comes first. Note that the default settings allow the last line to be partially obscured by a formatting rectangle that is not a whole multiple of the line height. To ensure that only whole lines are seen, specify this value and be careful to provide a formatting rectangle at least as tall as the height of one line.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringFormatFlags.NoClip
member.summary: Overhanging parts of glyphs, and unwrapped text reaching outside the formatting rectangle are allowed to show. By default all text and glyph parts reaching outside the formatting rectangle are clipped.

member.name: T:System.Drawing.StringTrimming
member.summary: Specifies how to trim characters from a string that does not completely fit into a layout shape.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.None
member.summary: Specifies no trimming.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.Character
member.summary: Specifies that the text is trimmed to the nearest character.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.Word
member.summary: Specifies that text is trimmed to the nearest word.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.EllipsisCharacter
member.summary: Specifies that the text is trimmed to the nearest character, and an ellipsis is inserted at the end of a trimmed line.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.EllipsisWord
member.summary: Specifies that text is trimmed to the nearest word, and an ellipsis is inserted at the end of a trimmed line.

member.name: F:System.Drawing.StringTrimming.EllipsisPath
member.summary: The center is removed from trimmed lines and replaced by an ellipsis. The algorithm keeps as much of the last slash-delimited segment of the line as possible.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that certain members on a specified are accessed dynamically, for example through .
member.remarks:
This allows tools to understand which members are being accessed during the execution of a program.
This attribute is valid on members whose type is or .
When this attribute is applied to a location of type , the assumption is that the string represents a fully qualified type name.
When this attribute is applied to a class, interface, or struct, the members specified can be accessed dynamically on instances returned from calling on instances of that class, interface, or struct.
If the attribute is applied to a method it's treated as a special case and it implies the attribute should be applied to the "this" parameter of the method. As such the attribute should only be used on instance methods of types assignable to System.Type (or string, but no methods will use it there).

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute.#ctor(System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified member types.
member.param: The types of members dynamically accessed.

member.summary: Gets the which specifies the type of members dynamically accessed.

member.summary: Specifies the types of members that are dynamically accessed. This enumeration has a attribute that allows a bitwise combination of its member values.

member.summary: Specifies all members.
